Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US — a land where anyone from anywhere can pick themselves up, put down roots, start anew, thrive, succeed—in other words, a land of ever-growing opportunity; a land where the taxpayers pay for everything thrice over; where immigrant communities without first having gone home and tried vaccination in their own

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to the lush tragedies of love and war being played out. But after attempting to tell the life stories of three people and try to explore the dynamics of a nation-half colonised by a foreign power, the film fails by being too ambitious.
Ethan Rutherford

After watching this movie, I couldn't help but notice the parallels between it and another film called America 3000. Both were very bad mid 1980's scifi movies that feature a girl who fantasizes about robots (like Wall-e) and ultimately winds up on some planet that requires her to hit golf balls into a wall.
